response.answer_text: Boston, Lincolnshire. Almost picture-postcard English – middling market town and port on the east coast, actually not on the coast any more. Very flat, surrounding area is market gardening country heavily dependent on seasonal labour for picking and processing. Spectacular medieval church tower, the Stump, speaks of former wealth. The Mayflower sailed from there. Boston, Massachussetts. City of the north-eastern United States. Many people of Irish heritage. Said to be the most corrupt and most civilised city in America. Fiefdom of the Kennedys. Some of the most dreadful bad driving to be seen anywhere. Home of Legal Seafood and Sam Adams Ale. Feels more European than any other American city. Named after the above.

Are we talking Boston, Lincolnshire, or Boston, Massachusetts? Boston, Lincs is 100% British. It is in Great Britain, after all. Boston, MA is not very British. It’s got a few faux-British pubs and a couple of branches of Wagamama, but mostly, this is the place where the Americans ran the British out of the US. Tea was involved somehow, I recall… Seriously though, I’d say Boston, whilst not being specifically very British, is quite European in appearance and attitudes, certainly compared to most other US cities. Everything is a stage or two older than you see around most of the rest of the US, the city is not based around a grid system, there’s widespread use of public transport (the Boston T reminds me of parts of the Tube, with similar signage) and you’ll find a generally more European, egalitarian mindset amongst many of its residents. It’s also a place where you’ll find a lot of “old money” upper-class types, the closest thing the US has to a ‘landed gentry’.
